fields.description: After install Eucalyptus 3.0 i sought memory leak. Solution - update to version 3.1. I updated. but it didn't help. You can see this on graph below. now running 8 instances.

comments.body: QUESTION: How do we identify a potential memory leak condition and differentiate it from high memory utilization?
swap graph
memory graph
Monitoring httpd using "top -b " grows 360MB a day on a Cent OS 6.2 CC+NC setup without any activity . Likewise a Ubunto 12 setup does not show the same behaviour, memory usage stays level.

[root@eucahost-51-75 eucalyptus]# rpm -qa | grep httpd
httpd-2.2.15-15.el6.centos.1.x86_64

Yestarday:
[root@eucalyptus eucalyptus]# top -b | grep httpd
 5135 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S 46.7  9.0  27:03.91 httpd                                                                                                                
 4340 root      18   0 82684 1680  828 S  0.0  0.0   0:02.19 httpd                                                                                                                
 4341 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  0.0  9.0  27:22.04 httpd                                                                                                                
 4342 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  0.0  9.0  26:28.92 httpd                                                                                                                
 4343 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  0.0  9.0  26:22.37 httpd                                                                                                                
 4344 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  0.0  9.0  26:28.60 httpd                                                                                                                
 4346 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  0.0  9.0  27:16.46 httpd                                                                                                                
 5131 eucalypt  15   0  814m 117m 115m S  0.0  3.0   6:17.42 httpd                                                                                                                
 4343 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  7.2  9.0  26:22.59 httpd                                                                                                                
 4346 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  1.6  9.0  27:16.51 httpd                                                                                                                
 4341 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  1.3  9.0  27:22.08 httpd                                                                                                                
 4342 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  1.3  9.0  26:28.96 httpd                                                                                                                
 4344 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  1.3  9.0  26:28.64 httpd                                                                                                                
 5135 eucalypt  15   0 1058m 354m 106m S  1.0  9.0  27:03.94 httpd

Today:

[root@eucalyptus eucalyptus]# top -b | grep httpd
 4340 root      18   0 82684  952  696 S  0.0  0.0   0:03.06 httpd                                                                                                                
 4341 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 448m 106m S  0.0 11.4  38:32.10 httpd                                                                                                                
 4342 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 445m 106m S  0.0 11.3  37:28.18 httpd                                                                                                                
 4343 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 447m 106m S  0.0 11.4  37:19.69 httpd                                                                                                                
 4344 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 447m 106m S  0.0 11.4  37:26.39 httpd                                                                                                                
 4346 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 450m 106m S  0.0 11.4  38:24.97 httpd                                                                                                                
 5131 eucalypt  15   0  814m 116m 115m S  0.0  3.0   8:49.13 httpd                                                                                                                
 5135 eucalypt  15   0 1157m 449m 106m S  0.0 11.4  38:11.00 httpd     


On Mon Aug 06 11:16:08 2012, neil.beard wrote:

Hide quoted text
> Good Morning Gennady, Our engineering team have found the following.
> Monitoring httpd using "top -b " grows 360MB a day on a Cent OS 6.2
> CC+NC setup
> without any activity . Could you check to see that you see the same
> symptoms.
> Thank you! Neil Beard

1. I have eliminated CLC portion of the memory growth by monitoring the clc components using VisualVM and the GC keeps the Java pieces under control.

2. Returning to httpd activity, there is obsoletely no memory consumption on a Ubunto 12 system with Apache/Axis2 packages (these are all much later than Cent-OS 6.2 pieces ) :

root@eucahost-51-171:/var/log/eucalyptus# dpkg -l | egrep "apac|axis" | cut -c1-60
ii  apache2                               2.2.22-1ubuntu1   
ii  apache2-mpm-worker                    2.2.22-1ubuntu1   
ii  apache2-utils                         2.2.22-1ubuntu1   
ii  apache2.2-bin                         2.2.22-1ubuntu1   
ii  apache2.2-common                      2.2.22-1ubuntu1   
ii  libapache-pom-java                    10-2              
ii  libapache2-mod-axis2c                 1.6.0-0ubuntu14   
ii  libaxis2c0                            1.6.0-0ubuntu14   

Cent-OS packages:


[root@eucahost-51-75 httpd-2.2.15]# rpm -qa | egrep "http|axis"
axis2c-devel-1.6.0-0.4.el6.x86_64
axis2-java2wsdl-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch
axis2-adb-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch
axis2-poms-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch
axis2c-1.6.0-0.4.el6.x86_64
httpd-tools-2.2.15-15.el6.centos.1.x86_64
httpd-2.2.15-15.el6.centos.1.x86_64
jakarta-commons-httpclient-3.1-0.6.el6.x86_64
hc-httpcore-4.0-1.jpp5.noarch
axis2-kernel-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch
axis2-codegen-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch
axis-1.2.1-7.2.el6.noarch
axis2-adb-codegen-1.4.1-1.jpp5.noarch

Restarting the cc kills/restarts the httpd and frees the memory.

I've built debug versions of httpd-2.2.15  from source along with the Eucalyptus axis2 services ( /usr/lib64/axis2c/services/EucalyptusCC/libEucalyptusCC.so ).

Monitoring malloc and free calls within EucalyptusCC/libEucalyptusCC.so using gdb 
I don't see any paths that indicate  a memory leak in Eucalyputs. The only activity going on through the httpd services are requests to DescribeResourcesMarshal() .
 
Upon examining httpd process created by /etc/init.d/eucalyptus-cc, there are 84 unique libraries loaded in the executed ( as reported vt /proc/<pid>/maps ) .
Anyone one of these could be cause.

I installed Valgrind to run the memory leak detector. It showed a couple of 
possible leaks in underlying libraries :


==1383== 163,840 bytes in 20 blocks are possibly lost in loss record 420 of 420
==1383==    at 0x4A0688E: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:270)
==1383==    by 0x5CF9062: apr_pool_create_ex (in /usr/lib64/libapr-1.so.0.3.9)
==1383==    by 0x52F7FA6: apr_hook_sort_all (in /usr/lib64/libaprutil-1.so.0.3.9)
==1383==    by 0x136F4C: ap_setup_prelinked_modules (config.c:707)
==1383==    by 0x11EF54: main (main.c:507)
==1383==
==1383== LEAK SUMMARY:
==1383==    definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==1383==    indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==1383==      possibly lost: 1,677,512 bytes in 1,737 blocks
==1383==    still reachable: 349,520 bytes in 524 blocks
==1383==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==1383==

CentOS 6.2 system:

The libs associated with httpd:

[root@eucahost-51-75 eucalyptus]# cat /proc/3170/maps | grep lib | cut -c60-120 | sort | uniq 
              /disk1/storage/eucalyptus/var/lib/eucalyptus/CC

fwiiw : our version of  AXIS  does have 1 minor memory leak that occurs when stack is built: 

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AXIS2C-1561

ve been monitoring the RSS size of the httpd process that 
runs the Steady State reporting by adding memory alloc trace code into the EucalyptusCC.so  library for:

 describeServices 
 describeResources 
 describeInstances 
 describeNetworks 
 describePublicAddresses

Neither valgrind nor mtrace(2) showed any leaks.

Here is my theory.

Memory fragmentation.

These functions:

DescribeResourcesMarshal:864, alloc size: 587200, addr: 0x7f2a58091370, 

and

DescribeNetworksMarshal:337, alloc size: 105829072, addr: 0x7f2a26237010, 

Both allocate large buffers, do some work, then releases them.

Likely because of a small trickle of a leak in the axis2c, or any of the 72 libs.so,
or  memory fragmentation as the process ages,  these large allocations expand the 
RSS of the  process by a moderate number of pages every couple passes
to accommodate the request to provide a contiguous chunk of memory.

I modified these functions to allocate the buffers only once  and it seems to 
have an impact in limiting the RSS high water mark of 245000k:

[root@eucahost-51-75 cluster]# top -b | grep http 
11249 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 215m 108m S  5.9  2.7  14:14.20 httpd                                                           
11261 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 215m 108m S  2.0  2.7  41:14.30 httpd                                                           
11228 root      20   0 58460 1712 1068 S  0.0  0.0   0:07.50 httpd                                                           
11229 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 215m 108m S  0.0  2.7   1:21.89 httpd                                                           
11230 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 214m 108m S  0.0  2.7   1:34.38 httpd                                                           
11231 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 214m 108m S  0.0  2.7   7:13.33 httpd                                                           
11232 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 214m 108m S  0.0  2.7   1:07.19 httpd                                                           
11233 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 215m 108m S  0.0  2.7   2:56.05 httpd                                                           
11260 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 215m 108m S  0.0  2.7   0:04.14 httpd                                                           
11948 eucalypt  20   0 1041m 120m 115m S  0.0  1.5  18:37.20 httpd                                                           
13903 eucalypt  20   0 1142m 108m 1404 T  0.0  1.4   0:00.00 httpd         



On a system where these allocations are repeated and release, RSS grows:

[root@eucahost-51-157 eucalyptus]# top -b | grep http
30570 root      20   0 56180 1512  864 S  0.0  0.0   0:09.51 httpd                                                           
30571 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:14.93 httpd                                                           
30572 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:13.12 httpd                                                           
30573 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:15.55 httpd                                                           
30574 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:09.76 httpd                                                           
30575 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:09.60 httpd                                                           
31438 eucalypt  20   0  838m 118m 115m S  0.0  1.5  12:05.38 httpd                                                           
32346 eucalypt  20   0 1138m 411m 107m S  0.0  5.2  36:15.32 httpd  

  ( update : I was using libraries built from source )

I have built axis2c.1.6.0  from source to get accurate symbol 
information for mtrace and valgrind that produces these libraries:

[root@b-13 libs]# ls libax*6*0
libaxis2_axiom.so.0.6.0          libaxis2_mod_log.so.0.6.0
libaxis2_engine.so.0.6.0         libaxis2_parser.so.0.6.0
libaxis2_http_common.so.0.6.0    libaxis2_tcp_receiver.so.0.6.0
libaxis2_http_receiver.so.0.6.0  libaxis2_tcp_sender.so.0.6.0
libaxis2_http_sender.so.0.6.0    libaxis2_xpath.so.0.6.0
libaxis2_mod_addr.so.0.6.0       libaxutil.so.0.6.0

I discovered that when I replace /usr/lib64/libaxis2_parser.so.0.6.0
with the one built from source the memory consumption stops.

[~jdonnelly], that's a good find.  So, there are at least two things worth comparing:

* how does the patchset for the code you built differ from what we package in RPM form?
* how does the build procedure (config options, compiler flags, etc.) differ between your build from source and what we package in RPM form?

- downloaded axis2C-1.6.0.04.el4 src from 

http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/devel/packages/3-devel/rhel/6/source/ .. is that there as a convenience  or do we built it ?


  1. memory growth symptom is reproducible using the built libaxis2_parser on Centos 6.3 .

   The 6 patches applied don't seem that severe .

   I'll work through the individual ones  and see where they lead.

We do actually build and ship it.  That source rpm should be the right one.  It should also be posted in http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/eucalyptus/3.1/centos/6/source/ ... but is not for some reason.  There should also be a corresponding debuginfo package available, which would allow you to run gdb and other debug tools against the rpm.  I'll work with [~gholms] and [~mspaulding] to make sure we get that posted, too.

1. If I build the libaxis2_parser.so.0.6.0 directly from the 
axis2c-1.6.0.gz source included in 1.6.0.04 rpm , it does not show the 
memory growth. ( it builds  using -Werror which patch6 in the spec file removes)

2. It appears the patches 1-5 may not have any to do the memory growth. 

In the axis.spec:
%prep
%setup -q -n %{name}-src-%{version}
#%patch1 -p1
#%patch2 -p1
#%patch3 -p1
#%patch4 -p1
#%patch5 -p1
%patch6 -p1


only applying patch6 (because it won't build
without it: error cc1: warnings being treated as errors
ssl/ssl_utils.c: In function 'axis2_ssl_utils_initialize_ctx':
ssl/ssl_utils.c:66: error: assignment discards qualifiers from pointer target type
)

The growth returns. 

Will the product  work without these patches ? euca-describe-services indicates the 
subsystems are ENABLED.

Patch 6 in that RPM only does one thing, which is to disable the "-Werror" compiler flag.  In the past, that was only needed for Fedora, and we now use wso2's axis2c on Fedora anyway, so that patch should probably be removed.  The patch is a hack anyway, because rather than fixing the real problem, it's telling the compiler to ignore it.

The other patches are documented in the spec file:

{quote}
# Fix documentation destdir (fixed upstream)
Patch1:         axis2c-1.6.0-destdir.patch
# https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AXIS2C-1512
Patch2:         axis2c-1.6.0-envpath.patch
# https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AXIS2C-1521
Patch3:         axis2c-1.6.0-sslctx.patch
# https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AXIS2C-1522
Patch4:         axis2c-1.6.0-curlinit.patch
# Fix linking DSO issues (is this upstream?)
Patch5:         axis2c-1.6.0-dso.patch
{quote}

The code probably works without any of them, but some of them address important security issues.  All are there for a reason, but it's certainly possible that one of them has introduced a leak.
Specifically, for the 3 with upstream Jira issues, I would recommend reviewing the upstream issues and verifying the the patch we are using matches what actually got committed upstream in SVN.

from the spec :

/bin/sh ../libtool --tag=CC   --mode=compile gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I.. -I../include -I ../../util/include    -g -O2 -D_LARGEFILE64_SOURCE -DAXIS2_GUTHTHILA_ENABLED -ansi -ggdb3 -Wall -Wno-implicit-function-declaration  -MT guththila_xml_parser.lo -MD -MP -MF .deps/guththila_xml_parser.Tpo -c -o guththila_xml_parser.lo guththila_xml_parser.c

between building the default axis2 package 1.6.0 from source 
and RPM is the spec file uses  libxml2:


[root@b-13 eucalyptus]# rpm -qa | grep xml2
libxml2-devel-2.7.6-8.el6_3.3.x86_64
libxml2-python-2.7.6-8.el6_3.3.x86_64
libxml2-2.7.6-8.el6_3.3.x86_64

removing it libxml2 removes the memory leak. 
 

spec file change:

#./configure --prefix=%{axis2c_home} --libdir=%{_libdir} --with-apache2=%{_includedir}/httpd --with-apr=%{_includedir}/apr-1 --disable-static --with-gnu-ld --with-pic --enable-libcurl --enable-libxml2 --enable-openssl --enable-tcp

to

./configure --prefix=%{axis2c_home} --libdir=%{_libdir} --with-apache2=%{_includedir}/httpd --with-apr=%{_includedir}/apr-1 --disable-static --with-gnu-ld --with-pic --enable-libcurl --enable-openssl --enable-tcp
make %{?_smp_mflags}


There are much later versions of libxlm2:

ftp://xmlsoft.org/libxml2/

The most recent is 2.9.0 , dated 9/2012 .

Most recent libxml2  2.9.0 rpm has additional dependencies :

rpm -ivh :
  
warning: libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64.rpm: Header V4 DSA/SHA1 Signature, key ID de95bc1f: NOKEY
error: Failed dependencies:
	libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.14)(64bit) is needed by libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64
	libc.so.6(GLIBC_2.15)(64bit) is needed by libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64
	liblzma.so.5()(64bit) is needed by libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64
	libz.so.1(ZLIB_1.2.2.3)(64bit) is needed by libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64
	libz.so.1(ZLIB_1.2.3.3)(64bit) is needed by libxml2-2.9.0-1.x86_64

It is generally not safe to grab an RPM from another distro version and install it without recompiling, even when dependencies are met.  Even if it worked, it would be an unsupported configuration (from a Red Hat perspective, at least).

I think the leap from "{{--enable-libxml2}} causes the problem" to "libxml2 has a leak" requires more explanation.  It is necessary to look at how that enablement actually changes the program.  The only code that this flag appears to change is code inside the {{#ifdef AXIS2_LIBXML2_ENABLED}} blocks in axiom/src/om/om_stax_builder.c, and consists of two calls to axiom_stax_builder_create_om_element (with AXIS2_FALSE instead of AXIS2_TRUE for the third argument), and five calls to axiom_xml_reader_xml_free rather than AXIS2_FREE.  

The leak *might* be in libxml2's xmlFree function, which is eventually what gets called by axiom_xml_reader_xml_free, but from reading things like https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AXIS2C-1236 and http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/axis-c-user/200803.mbox/%3C6463f4210803281238l797d1321ja1e2e2922e7b497a@mail.gmail.com%3E it seems there is also the possibility that we just haven't configured the server correctly or haven't done some things to manage libxml2 correctly. 

All that said, given that libxml2 is *not* the default parser, and there are some reports of leak possibilities with it, _and_ you aren't seeing the leak with it disabled, its seems completely reasonable for us to switch to guththilla, the default parser/reader.

After visiting the site for libxml2 , the first step they requested
is to verify the problem is resolved in a later release.

I'll review these defects. Looking at some of the Axis2c functions created by the 
euca-WSDL2C.sh in cluster/generated/ the wrappers created use the AXIS2_FREE API. 

Is it appropriate for us to turn libxml2 off ? Of course what are 
the consequences using guththila then ?

Has libxml2 always been the default axiom parser component ?

It has been for the version Eucalyptus has shipped, at least.  At the time it was much easier to use libxml2 than it was to unbundle guththila and use that since the former is already in every distro.  That, plus the fact that guththila's last release was in 2005 and the fact that everything else in every distro uses libxml2 made it seem an obvious choice, but, yeah...

I don't see any insurmountable roadblocks to changing.  We'd need to test the crap out of it, though, seeing as the anti-memory-leak patches we've applied to axis2c actually cause double-frees and weird register corruption in code paths that Eucalyptus currently manages to dodge.  Well, that and the fact that guththila doesn't have a massive user base testing it and fixing bugs.  But it certainly might be worth a shot.
[~gholms] -- I note that you mention _unbundling_ guththilla in order to use it.  any particular reason?  Can't it just be build into axis2c, or as a subpackage?

I'm uploading the new axis2c build now so we can do broader testing against it.
Uploaded axis2c-1.6.0-0.5.el6, which doesn't use libxml2 any more.  Shall we test if using it fixes the memory leak?
Note that we still use libxml2 elsewhere, such as in the fault subsystem.
